fields.title: Advertise
fields.content:
Program Underwriting

If you would like to underwrite the Columbia Orchestra's programming, with your underwriting message seen in our 2010-2011 concert programs by thousands of concertgoers, you may either sponsor a specific activity (a concert, a soloist or a competition) or simply take out an ad in our printed concert programs. To sponsor a specific activity, please download a Sponsorship form in PDF format. For an ad in our printed concert programs, please download an Underwriting form in PDF format.The forms are suitable for printing; simply fill out the appropriate form and return it to the address on the form. Viewing and printing these files requires Adobe Acrobat Reader.

Please click here for Underwriting Facts to find out more about our season, reach, and program specifications.

2010-2011 Concert Season

See your advertisement in the following programs!

  • Classical Concert 2
    Saturday, December 4, 2010
    Rouse Theatre
  • Young People's Concerts
    Saturday, January 8, 2011
    Rouse Theatre
  • Symphonic Pops Concert
    Saturday, February 12, 2011
    Rouse Theatre
  • Classical Concert 3
    Saturday, March 26, 2011
    Rouse Theatre
  • Classical Concert 4
    Saturday, June 4, 2011
    Rouse Theatre

The levels of underwriting and/or advertisement size are as follows:

  • Concert Sponsor $5,000
    Includes corporate logo and/or company name in all season and concert press releases and printed materials pertaining to selected program, plus a full-page advertisement (6" wide x 7.5" high), website logo and link, complimentary tickets, concert banner, and lobby display.
  • Soloist Sponsor $2,500
    Includes company name in all press releases and printed materials pertaining to selected soloist, plus a half-page advertisement (6" wide x 3.75" high), website logo and link, complimentary tickets, and concert banner.
  • Competition Sponsor (Young Artist Competition, American Composer Competition) $1,000
    Includes company name in all printed materials pertaining to selected event, plus a business-card advertisement (3.5" wide x 2" high), website link, and complimentary tickets.
  • Back or inside cover full-page color advertisement (6" wide x 7.5" high) SOLD OUT
    An extra 500 program covers will be printed for chamber music programs
  • Full-page black&white advertisement (6" wide x 7.5" high) $425
  • Half-page black&white advertisement (6" wide x 3.75" high) $250
  • Business card black&white advertisement (3.5" wide x 2" high or 2" wide x 3.5" high) $160

BLACK & WHITE CAMERA-READY ARTWORK OR DIGITAL FILE DUE BY November 24, 2010.

An additional fee of $50 will be assessed for any artwork that must be modified.

If you have any questions, please contact us at 410-465-8777 or by e-mail at execdir@columbiaorchestra.org.

Go directly to AMAZON by clicking on this AMAZON button. It appears here and at the bottom of all of our web pages. AMAZON will donate a percentage of all purchases you make to the orchestra .

Once the button has been clicked, a separate AMAZON window will appear. Use this window for your AMAZON shopping. If you close the window, no problem. Just click on any of our AMAZON buttons and a new window will open for you.

Make your visit to AMAZON more efficient by specifying search criteria and clicking on the gold GO button.

fields.title: Auditions
fields.content:
Join the Columbia Orchestra

If you play an orchestral instrument and enjoy the challenge of playing the best of the symphonic repertoire with an inspiring conductor, you don't want to miss the opportunity to join the Columbia Orchestra of Howard County, Maryland. The Columbia Orchestra is a volunteer adult community orchestra dedicated to fostering a lifelong appreciation of and participation in classical music. Advanced high school students are welcome. Come join us for an exciting season performing great music! We keep an active substitute list, so don't hesitate to contact us.

Now how do you join? By auditioning for us at the auditions typically held near the end of August. We also have a limited number of audition times during the season, so if you miss our August auditions but are still interested, please contact annesward@comcast.net or 410-465-8777, extension 4.

If the thought of preparing an audition frightens you, please remember - we are a friendly group of people who love to play music together, and we want to make joining us a fun experience for you!

Audition Requirements (to last no longer than 15 minutes total)

  • Two octave major and minor scales through 3b and 3# (articulated/slurred as you wish)
  • 2 prepared pieces of contrasting nature (orchestral/concerto excerpts are acceptable)
  • Sight-reading at the discretion of the Music Director

Please look around our web site to familiarize yourself with our orchestra. Here are some specific items you may be interested in:

  • Rehearsal Schedule
  • Rehearsal Locations
  • Concert Season

Auditions will be held Sunday, August 15, 2010 1:00 – 5:00 PM and Monday, August 16, 2010 7:00 – 10:00 PM at Christ Episcopal Church, 6800 Oakland Mills Road, Columbia. for the following:

  • Permanent positions Second Clarinet, Third/Auxiliary Clarinet (E-Flat, Bass), Section Percussion, and for all strings
  • Substitute list for woodwinds, brass, and percussion

For more information, please contact annesward@comcast.net or 410-465-8777, extension 4.

fields.title: Composer Competition
fields.content:
American Composer Competition

The Columbia Orchestra began its American Composer Competition in 2003 to help promote new American works both locally and across the United States. The winning work receives its first, second, or third public performance, thereby expanding the performance history for music worthy to be heard again and again. The winner also receives a cash prize and a additional stipend if attendance at the concert and rehearsals is possible.

The next American Composer Competition is scheduled for 2011.

The winning work of the 2009 American Composer Competition was the Third Movement of Symphony No. 1 “Remembrance” by Albert Hurwit. The orchestra performed the work on December 5, 2009 with the composer in attendance.

The orchestra received 124 submissions from throughout the United States. In addition to the winning work, seven finalists were selected (listed in alphabetic order):

  • Brian Fennelly: Reflections/Metamorphosis
  • Anthony Iannaccone: Dancing on Vesuvius
  • Mark Lackey: Convergence
  • Elizabeth Lim: Paranoia
  • Justin Merritt: River of Blood
  • Philip Rothman: Arc of Visibility
  • David Schneider: Automation

Congratulations to Dr. Hurwit, the finalists, and all who entered the competition. We are extremely grateful for your participation!

Read more about the winning work and the competition in this Press Release.

About Albert Hurwit

The composing career of Albert Hurwit began relatively late in his life. He was born in Hartford, Connecticut in 1931. After graduating from Harvard College and Tufts Medical School, he remained in Boston for four years of postgraduate radiology training. He returned to Hartford and practiced radiology until his retirement in 1986.

Through most of his life, Hurwit had been casually involved with music and composing in an unstructured manner. Since 1986 he has dedicated all of his energies to composing music. He has had no formal training, but has received informal mentoring form Robert Carl, Chairman of the Composition Department of the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford, and Michael Lankester, the former Music Director of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra.

In 1997 the Adaskin String Trio performed Hurwit’s “Adagio” at the University of Hartford. It was then expanded into an “Adagio for Orchestra,” which was performed later that year by the Hartford Symphony Orchestra with Michael Lankester conducting at the Bushnell Center for Performing Arts.

After three more years of self instruction, experimentation and musical exploration Hurwit began to compose a symphony. He completed the composition of Symphony No. 1 “Remembrance” in 2002.

On November 8, 9 and 10, 2002, Movement III of the symphony (electronic rendition) was choreographed by Peggy Lyman and performed by the Hartt School of Music Dancers at the Lincoln Theater of the University of Hartford.

On February 13 and 14, 2003, the third movement of this symphony was performed in a concert world premiere by the Hartford Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Edward Cumming at the Bushnell Center for Performing Arts.

In July of 2004, the symphony was recorded by the Bulgarian National Radio Symphony Orchestra with Michael Lankester conducting. Hurwit spent eight days in Sofia and participated in the rehearsing, revisions, recording, mixing and finalizing process of the CD production. The CD of the symphony was released by MSR Classics in March of 2005, and it is being distributed by Albany Records.

The West Hartford Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Richard Chiarappa presented world premiere concert performance of the entire Symphony No.1 “Remembrance” on March 5, 2006.

fields.title: Donate
fields.content:
Make a Donation

We are grateful to our many loyal supporters, and hope you too will support the orchestra. Ticket sales cover only 25% of our expenses. Your donation helps make it possible for us to rent concert and rehearsal space, contract outstanding soloists, rent and purchase music, and keep the community informed of our activities. By contributing to the orchestra, you help to enrich our community and to sustain the priceless cultural heritage of classical music. Please help the Columbia Orchestra keep making Your Community's Music.

Contributors will be acknowledged in our programs grouped into these giving levels:

  • FRIEND (up to $99)
  • DONOR ($100-$249)
  • PATRON ($250-$499)
  • BENEFACTOR ($500-$999)
  • SPONSOR ($1,000-$1,999)
  • CONDUCTOR'S CIRCLE ($2,000 and greater)

Thank you for your support. The Columbia Orchestra is incorporated in Maryland as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation. All donations are tax-deductible.

How to make a donation:


Click the button to make a donation online using a credit card.

All transactions are handled on a secure server hosted by PayPal. If you do not already have a PayPal account, you will have the option to paying with or without creating one. Simply click the button and follow the instructions. You will be asked to log in to your PayPal account. If you do not have a PayPal account, that is not a problem. You will have the options of paying with or without creating one. Your donation will be confirmed by e-mail, and you will receive a written acknowledgement and thank-you by mail. If you have any comments regarding the donation, type them in the 'Message to Seller (Optional)' section at the bottom of the 'Billing Information' page.

Make a donation by mail. First complete our donation form. Viewing and printing this form requires Adobe Acrobat Reader; if you don't have Acrobat Reader, you can download a free copy. Then mail the form along with a check to The Columbia Orchestra, sending it to the address at the bottom of this web page.

If you would like to make a non-cash donation to the orchestra, please contact the orchestra office at 410-465-8777. We will be happy to discuss other gifts with you.

If you would prefer that your donation remain anonymous, just let us know and we will honor your wishes.

The Columbia Orchestra is a 501(c)(3) organization—donations to which are tax deductible to the fullest extent allowed by law. A copy of our current financial statement is available upon request by calling our office. Documents submitted to the State of Maryland Charitable Solicitations Act are available from the Secretary of State, State House, Annapolis, MD 21401, for the cost of copying and mailing.

fields.title: History
fields.content:
History of the Columbia Orchestra

In the fall of 1977, a handful of local string players began playing classical music as the Columbia Chamber Orchestra. Yong Ku Ahn became the group's first Music Director and conductor in 1978.

Upon Ahn's retirement in 1988, Carl Dietrich took over leadership of the orchestra. During his tenure, the membership was expanded to include winds and percussion, standard symphonic literature was programmed, and the orchestra dropped "chamber" from its name.

Catherine Ferguson served as the Columbia Orchestra's third Music Director from 1990 until 1999, expanding the repertoire, restructuring the annual Young Artist Competition, establishing a regular season at Howard Community College's Smith Theatre, and leading the Columbia Orchestra's first appearance at the Columbia Festival of the Arts.

Current Music Director Jason Love took the podium in 1999, quickly winning the hearts of orchestra members and audience alike with his humor, generosity, and consummate musicianship. Under his baton, The Baltimore Sun named the Columbia Orchestra "Howard County's premier ensemble for instrumental music."

In August 2000, the orchestra hired Tedd Griepentrog as its first Executive Director. During the 2001-2002 season, all Masterworks programs were moved to the Jim Rouse Theatre to accommodate the expanded size of the orchestra and its growing audience. The Young People's Concert added a Musical Instrument Petting Zoo for children of all ages to see, hear, touch, and play orchestral instruments. In June 2002, the orchestra made its Kennedy Center debut in collaboration with the Tony Powell/Music & Movement dance ensemble. During its silver anniversary season, the Columbia Orchestra performed for the Maryland Music Educators Conference at the Baltimore Convention Center and announced its first biannual American Composer Competition.

In 2005, the organization established an administrative office at the Howard County Center for the Arts and released its first commercial recording, Flying Home: A Tribute to John Denver, performing with members and songwriters of the original John Denver Band. In June 2007, the orchestra joined renown fiddler and concert artist Mark O’Connor in a concert performed as part of the Columbia Festival of the Arts.

Celebrating it’s 30th Anniversary season, in 2008 the orchestra undertook a community arts project entitled “Embracing the Millions,” which enlisted members of the community area performing artists in exploring the questions raised by the world’s most famous symphony, Beethoven’s monumental Symphony No. 9. The project culminated in the orchestra’s performance of the symphony with local choral groups in April 2008.

Now in its fourth decade, the orchestra continues its annual Young Artist Competition and its biannual American Composer Competition. It has established a free chamber music series featuring members of the orchestra. Popular pre-concert discussions, conducted by Howard Community College’s William Scanlan Murphy and now sponsored by Baltimore-Washington Financial Advisors, routinely draw up to 20% of the evening’s concert audience. And the orchestra continues to perform not only the masterworks of the classical repertoire but also works by today’s new generation of composers, including Tan Dun, Osvaldo Goliov, Joan Tower, and Jonathan Leshnoff.

As it enters its 33rd season, The Columbia Orchestra is clearly matching its reputation as one of Howard Magazine’s “51 Things We Love About Living In Howard County.”

fields.title: Jonathan Bailey Holland Video Interview
fields.content:
Video Interviews With Jonathan Bailey Holland

Jonathan Discusses Motor City Dance Mix

Columbia Orchestra guest composer Jonathan Bailey Holland discusses his Motor City Dance Mix and his work at the Berklee School of Music where he teaches. Jonathan will be in attendance at the concert and speak at the pre-concert discussion on October 16, 2010 at the Jim Rouse Theatre in Columbia, MD.

Jonathan's Style and Recent Work

Jonathan is asked about his style of composing, his recent works, and his upcoming projects.

Mr. Holland's appearance is funded in part through Meet the Composer's MetLife Creative Connections program.

fields.title: Mailing List
fields.content:
Subscribe to the Mailing List

To subscribe to the mailing list, simply send an email to mailinglist@columbiaorchestra.org with your name, address, phone number, and email address.

Our Privacy Policy: We will never share your information with any outside individuals or organizations without your permission. Period! The sole purpose of our mailing list is to provide information about Columbia Orchestra events and activities to those who have expressed interest in the orchestra.

fields.title: Mission Statement
fields.content:
Columbia Orchestra Mission Statement

The Mission of the Columbia Orchestra is to foster lifelong appreciation of, enthusiasm for, and participation in music. This is accomplished by:

  • Providing the community with high-quality musical performances by a locally-based symphony orchestra
  • Providing area students, teachers, and educational institutions with a classical music resource
  • Providing local classical musicians with an opportunity to explore and perform great orchestral literature and chamber music

fields.title: Partners & Sponsors
fields.content:
Sponsors and Strategic Partnerships

The Columbia Orchestra gratefully acknowledges the following organizations and corporations which have provided us with support in the form of grants, in-kind donations, and other services.

The Orchestra also has a number of strategic partnerships with organizations to whom we supply chamber music, educational programs, and other services. If you would like to explore the possibility of a mutually beneficial partnership with the Orchestra, please contact our Executive Director at 410-465-8777 or by e-mail at execdir@columbiaorchestra.org.

fields.title: Preludes
fields.content:
Preludes

Sponsored by BWFA

The Columbia Orchestra presents a series of "Preludes," a discussion series held before each Classical Concert. This enlightening, entertaining series allows you to experience the stories and ideas behind the concert's selections in an interesting, informal setting. Each free session runs from 6:30-7:10 (Subscribers can still take advantage of priority seating at 7:10.)

Concertgoers everywhere agree that the more you know about the music you are hearing, the more you enjoy it. Our “Preludes” series is designed to offer you that knowledge in a way that is easy and fun. We hope that you will enhance your concert experience by joining us for each Prelude!

Join Bill Scanlan Murphy for an enlightening, entertaining pre-concert discussion.

About Bill Scanlan Murphy

Bill Scanlan Murphy was born in Glasgow, Scotland, in 1954 and holds an MA degree from the University of Oxford. A professionally complex life has included hosting radio shows (rock, classical, and documentary) for the BBC, writing music for television dramas and working with diverse performers ranging from the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra to the Beach Boys and Charles Manson. “Cease To Exist,” a radio documentary on the musical life of Manson, remains the most-listened-to documentary in the history of the BBC Radio One network.

A parallel career as a naval historian has resulted in a book on early submariners and numerous articles and radio features, including one on how many composers have been naval officers. Bill Scanlan Murphy currently teaches at Howard Community College and is Director of Music at Lovely Lane United Methodist Church in Baltimore.

fields.title: Press Room
fields.content:
Press Room

Aug 19, 2010: For our programming at a glance, download the 2010-2011 Season Overview in PDF format.

fields.title: Program Notes
fields.content:
Program Notes - Concert 5/22/10

by Bill Scanlan Murphy



JONATHAN BAILEY HOLLAND (born 1974)

MOTOR CITY DANCE MIX

Composed: 2005

Premiered: Detroit, 2005

Now a teacher of composition at Boston’s Berklee College of Music, Jonathan Bailey Holland is a native of Flint, Michigan. It is often instructive to see who taught any given composer, and try to spot elements of the guru in the disciple’s work. The results can be startling: who can hear Gustav Holst in the music of Elliott Carter? In the case of Jonathan Bailey Holland, the lyricism of Ned Rorem, with whom he studied at the Curtis Institute, and the steely serial sinews of the English composers Bernard Rands (his teacher at Harvard) and Robert Saxton are twisted together into a gritty but heartfelt emotional language that speaks directly to the modern American spirit. Elements of other musics flash by, only to be milled through the composer’s iron logic into the girders of entirely new musical structures.

Holland is fully aware of the forces acting on his music, and the paradox of the one-man polyculture which is any honest musician in the modern world:

I am as influenced by contemporary classical music as I am by jazz, rap, r&b, neosoul, and all other good music. I am fascinated by color, both visually and aurally. I strive to communicate with my music. I do not embrace one single style for all of my compositions. I aspire to have a recognizable voice.

And how does he attain that voice? It is interesting to compare what Holland has to say about his own music and his teaching methods with the structure of La Mer and the other key works of modern music:

I think a lot of times people think about theory as random rules on how notes have to go together. I'm trying to stress that nothing is random, that everything makes sense from point A to point Z, and that everything at point A is the same as everything at point Z, just on a smaller scale. If you look at one phrase of music, everything that happens in that phrase is similar to what happens over the course of the entire piece.

This is the core philosophy of the music of the last hundred years in three terse sentences. Everything derives from everything else and becomes everything else. Macro is micro; the end is the beginning. Whether the origin is Berry Gordy, disco, swing or Stravinsky – and all are present, one way or another, in Motor City Dance Mix – the aim of modern musical art is to bring the listener to the same focused point. The style wars of the late 1900s are over, and everybody won. All we have to do now is listen.

WOLFGANG AMADEUS MOZART (1756-1791)

CLARINET CONCERTO, K.622

Composed: 1791

Premiered: Prague, Austria-Hungary, 1791

I Allegro

II Adagio

III Rondo: Allegro

It seems difficult to imagine now, but writing a concerto for the clarinet in 1791 was like writing a work for synthesizer now. The instrument was still some way from establishing itself in the mainstream; indeed, there was even some debate over which instrument was the definitive clarinet. Mozart’s concerto, his last completed instrumental work, was not written for the modern clarinet, but for the basset clarinet; this was a hybrid of clarinet and basset horn, with a range extending a third below the clarinet and a darker, warmer sound than the instrument we now know. One early review of the concerto took Mozart to task for writing for this “bastard woodwind,” played by the work’s dedicatee, Anton Stadler. Mozart’s publisher took fright, and tinkered with the solo part after the composer’s death to make it playable on the “modern” clarinet; the original version of the concerto was not published until the twentieth century. The situation was not helped by the strange fact that Stadler fell onto hard times even worse than the dying Mozart’s soon after Mozart’s death, and pawned the original manuscript, which was never seen again. Nonetheless, it is the altered version for modern clarinet that has entered the repertoire, and the hearts of millions.

Given the imminent demise of the composer, it is easy to read foreboding and worse into Mozart’s last works, but the fact is that his late music, with few exceptions, has little to tell us of the strange storm of misery that broke over him late in 1790 and led to an unmarked grave only yards from the scenes of his musical triumphs. In the Clarinet Concerto, there is serenity rather than sadness, and more than a glimpse of the typically cheerful Mozartian allegro. The first movement’s exposition presents its famous first theme twice, with the soloist joining in on the second appearance, after which the music noticeably darkens. Strangely, there is no obvious place for a cadenza, where the soloist was originally invited to improvise intricate figurations around the movement’s material, a practice superseded (alas) by written cadenzas by about 1835; traditionally, the soloist inserts a few jeux d’esprit in a couple of gaps at the end of the exposition. Soon after this, we meet the strange phenomenon of the soloist accompanying the orchestra, playing an arpeggio figure (yes, an Alberti bass!) under the orchestra just before the recapitulation. This defiant demonstration of the wide range of this new-fangled woodwind returns just before the end of the movement.

The slow movement, as in so many of Mozart’s concerti, is the core of the work, presenting the simplest of material (one of Mozart’s best-known melodies) in the simplest ternary (A-B-A) form, with – finally – an opportunity for a true cadenza just before the reappearance of the main melody.

The finale is a typical Mozartian sonata-rondo, entirely free of the clouds that have occasionally drifted over the early movements. Herr Stadler once singled out the possibility of fast chromatic figuration as the single great advantage of the clarinet over the bucolic oboe, and here he got a chance to prove it. Both he and Mozart would soon be facing their separate demons, but this music has none.

CLAUDE DEBUSSY (1862-1918)

LA MER

Composed: 1903-1905

Premiered: Paris, France, 1905

I De l'aube à midi sur la mer (“From dawn to noon on the sea’) - Très lent (very slow)

II Jeux de vagues (“Play of the waves”) - Allegro

III Dialogue du vent et de la mer (“Dialogue of the wind and sea’) - Animé et tumultueux (Animated and tumultuous)

In one of the least-known (and certainly the funniest) documents of Debussy scholarship, his English nephew Frank de Bussy describes his Uncle Claude turning up in Manchester in 1905 with his heavily-pregnant girlfriend, Emma Bardac:

A truly, truly ‘orrible man. Rudest man I ever met. He were (sic) married to someone else at the time, and my mother wanted nothing to do with him and his fancy woman. We parceled him off to Eastbourne, first chance we got. He said he wanted to be at the seaside, and he wanted to see France. He could have swum back for all we cared.

Eastbourne was, and is, a moderately seedy resort town on the English Channel coast, and a good place for the Parisian lovebirds to nest while the scandal back home died down. And there was, indeed, a scandal. Emma was also married to someone else at the time, though it seems unlikely she even knew where her husband was by 1905. She had taken up with Debussy on the rebound from Gabriel Fauré, who in turn, incredibly, had taken up with her on the rebound from her daughter Helène. Emma was, at 43, a fairly matronly femme fatale. Unlike Emma’s husband, long lost in the steaming jungles of Emma’s amours, Debussy’s wife Lily was still very much in the picture. She made this very obvious by standing in the middle of Paris’s Place de la Concorde and shooting herself. She survived. Debussy’s name, however, became mud across Paris; hence the retreat to England.

On August 2, 1905, Debussy’s divorce from Lily became final. He and Emma were staying at the Grand Hotel, Eastbourne, The score of La Mer – The Sea - had been sitting completed on the desk for some days, but he chose this auspicious day to sign the manuscript and declare it finished. He was free, and his masterpiece was born; a daughter, Chou-Chou, followed in October. Claude and Emma were married in 1908.

La Mer is the closest that Debussy ever came to writing a symphony, but he called the work “Three Symphonic Sketches,” wishing to avoid the inevitable critical fallout from a declared attempt to follow in the footsteps of Beethoven. The actual oceanic symbolism of the piece has been debated since its first performance, when Debussy’s friend Pierre Lalo sighed “I neither hear, nor see, nor feel the sea.” Like so many composers, Debussy had been interested in the sea and maritime matters since childhood. Once, when asked in a questionnaire what he would have liked to be if not a composer, he scrawled “SAILOR!!” in huge capitals and underlined it twice. His legendarily terrifying political views once inspired an astonishingly detailed plan for the French navy that showed considerable genuine marine expertise among the demands for torrents of German blood.

If La Mer is indeed an evocation of the sea, it uses an aquatic vocabulary quite unlike that of any composer before Debussy; this is not the world of Scheherazade, far less that of The Flying Dutchman. Debussy loathed the very concept of “impressionism,” considering it a label slapped on him by ignorant, lazy critics. He would have preferred “Turnerist,” after his hero, the English painter J.M.W. Turner, whose seascapes evoked the power and moods of the ocean without ever depicting it in formal detail. In the work of both artists, spray becomes dabs of color; waves become the merest suggestion of uncertainty underfoot. Not a windblown arpeggio or quoted sea-shanty in sight. And look at the finale: motifs from the first movement return with a formal grandeur long familiar from the symphonies of Tchaikovsky and even more from the later symphonies of Sibelius. Close analysis of the music reveals an unmistakable organic growth of the music from material heard in the first few bars, all held together within a mathematically-derived framework derived from the Golden Section. This elusive, emotionally vague music is constructed like a watch. There is as much Cubism as Impressionism here.

Alas, La Mer, Debussy’s greatest orchestra work, was very nearly his last. Within a year of its completion, the cancer that would carry him off in agony during the German bombardment of Paris had begun to make its presence felt. Mercifully, he did not live to see the worst aftershock of the upheavals of 1905: less than a year after burying her husband, Emma watched their daughter Chou-Chou die of diphtheria.

Program Notes - Concert 5/22/10

by Bill Scanlan Murphy


WOLFGANG AMADEUS MOZART (1759–1792)

PIANO CONCERTO in D Minor, K. 466
 COMPOSED: 1785
PREMIERED: Vienna, 1785
I: Allegro
II: Romanza
III: Allegro assai; alla breve

This curiously dark work is one of only two of Mozart’s 27 piano concerti to be written in a minor key. That the first performance could barely be heard over the background noise in the Mehlgrube Casino probably contributed to the gloom, as did the fact that Mozart had barely finished it when he took his seat at the piano. The premiere was, in fact, a scramble. As his father wrote to Mozart’s sister Nannerl:

    I heard an excellent new piano concerto by Wolfgang, on which the copyist was still at work when we got there, and your brother didn't even have time to play through the rondo because he had to oversee the copying operation.
Mozart conducted frantically from the keyboard, nodding occasionally to the terrified concertmaster, whose suspicion that the only full score was still in Mozart´s head was entirely justified. There would be similar scenes nearly 150 years later, as George Gershwin nodded to Paul Whiteman to tell him the (improvised!) piano solo sections were about to end during the first performance of Rhapsody in Blue. Mozart’s audience consisted of what his obsessively class-conscious father called “a vast concourse of people of rank,” hovering between his son’s music and the gaming tables. Only the previous evening, Joseph Haydn had told Leopold that Wolfgang was “the greatest composer known to me, either personally or be reputation,” yet here he was now, struggling for attention.

A month earlier, the Mehlgrube’s star attraction had been the blind pianist Maria Theresia von Paradis (for whom Mozart wrote a concerto); the month before, there had been a conjurer. As always, the composer’s social standing teetered between very shaky popular adulation and the wow-but-so-what feeling that now (briefly) meets the denizens of American Idol. This hovering between the worlds of the courtly flunky and popular stardom (no problem at all for musicians only fifty years later) was an important factor in his ultimate impoverishment and early death. It’s therefore all the more surprising that Mozart chose an occasion like this to launch one of his darkest, most searching works.

The first movement opens with—no, not the first subject of the inevitable sonata form opener. Instead, we hear motifs—fragments that together add up to thematic material, an astonishing foreshadowing of the gigantic mosaics of Wagner, set over nagging, syncopated string chords. Instead of the usual setting out of the structural shop that we expect at the opening of a Classical concerto, we instead are offered what can only be called mood-setting. It is only when the piano enters that our old friends A and B become clearly audible. There would be nothing like this again until the concertos of Beethoven, who revered this work and played it in public several times. Indeed, it is Beethoven’s cadenzas that we are hearing this evening in the first and last movements.

Like Beethoven after him, Mozart often carried out his more outrageous formal experiments in his slow movements, and this concerto has a vivid example in its rondo structure—easily the least likely form to be expected here (not least because this movement is followed by another one). Even less likely is the dramatic lurch into G minor towards the end. Beethoven would often challenge himself (and us) with sudden plunges into distant keys, as though daring himself to find a way home; he may well have been inspired by Mozart’s leap into the tonal darkness here. Always civilized and precise, of course (it’s Mozart, after all), but with the faintest cracks and shadows in the porcelain. Nor should we forget that Mozart reserved his darkest thoughts (think of the fortieth symphony) for the key of G minor.

The Finale is the rondo we might expect—but, once again, G minor lurks in the tonal forest. It is not hard to believe that Mozart looked at that Casino audience and saw, not the career-saving Fairy Godfather that his father saw that day, but the Wolf. The concerto’s optimistic D major ending barely dissipates the darkness. Only seven years later, Mozart would be in an unmarked grave barely ten blocks from the Casino.


GUSTAV MAHLER (1860–1911)

SYMPHONY No. 1 in D
 COMPOSED: 1884–88
PREMIERED: Budapest, Hungary, 1889

No, not the Titan. Mahler ditched the subtitle early in this work’s tortuous early history (read on!). His wife, the later much-married Alma, could never bear listening to the First Symphony, because she knew what it was about; few wives (and certainly not one as independent of spirit as Alma) wish to wallow in the murky history of their husband’s love lives.

The Symphony began as music inspired by the soprano Johanna Richter, with whom Mahler had an absurdly one-sided non-affair in 1884. This object lesson in unrequited love resulted firstly in the doom-laden Songs of a Wayfarer. One of these, the deceptively chirpy Ging heut’ Morgen, is tested to destruction in the first movement of the Symphony. Johanna claimed, absurdly, to be related to Mahler’s favorite author, Jean-Paul Richter. Jean-Paul’s most popular novel, Titan, rarely left Mahler’s bedside. The book’s intimidating structure—35 chapters and 146 sub-chapters—has been cited as an arguable origin for Mahler’s later symphonic giantism, but rather more to the point is Jean-Paul’s concept of the hoher Mensch, the “superior man” that would eventually morph, at least for Mahler, into the Nietzschean Übermensch. The fact that Jean-Paul tells his tale in the form of a gargantuan, overwrought fairy-tale very nearly gives us Mahler’s musical thinking in a nutshell.

After Fräulein Richter ditched him, Mahler embarked on a guilt-ridden liaison with Marion Weber, the wife of Carl Maria von Weber’s grandson, made all the worse by the fact that her husband was trusting him with editing the musical heritage of his grandfather, who was one of Mahler’s heroes. Mahler was not Wagner, and, unlike the Sage of Bayreuth, had a conscience; the halting, fumbling, emotionally frantic result suggests what might have happened happen if Schiller edited Peyton Place; the musical spin-off was Mahler’s incidental music for Joseph Victor von Scheffel’s play Der Trompeter von Säckingen. This music also found its way into the Symphony, only to be thrown out again. Like Mahler himself, one might say.

Symphony? Not originally. Mahler launched the work as a “Titan, a Symphonic Poem in Two Parts.” Following Jean-Paul’s baleful example, Mahler subdivided the two parts into three and two movements respectively. The second movement, Blumine, was the recycled Trompeter von Säckingen music; traumatic events with Marion Weber house resulted in Mahler scrapping the movement after its second performance, in 1894. It would lie forgotten until resurrected by (curiously) Benjamin Britten in 1967. Not entirely helpfully, Mahler supplied the audience with detailed program notes linking the music to Jean-Paul’s epic; an unappreciative Budapest audience laughed the work off the stage. Mahler admitted at the time that he had made up the programmatic content after writing the music. An old story in the ever-deceptive emotional world of Romanticism.

It was only in 1896 that the Symphony finally appeared in its present form, minus Blumine and without its title. It was now the Symphony in D for Large Orchestra, and so it remains today. Ironically, the Berlin critics slammed the work for its lack of programmatic content.

This apparent indecision points to the very heart of Mahler’s music. The Funeral March of Beethoven’s Eroica symphony evokes—in advance—the departed Napoleon; Mahler’s Funeral March is a mangled Frère Jacques, and suggests the obsequies for an unfortunate puppet. This sort of irony was always going to cause Mahler problems with an audience that liked its emotions untainted; indeed, it would be the 1960s before his music achieved the popularity it deserved. Two World Wars, grimly foreseen by Nietzsche, had made the old Romanticism not merely impossible but unbearable.

The first movement, based largely on the song Ging heut’ Morgen (not so much inspired as caused by Johanna Richter), emerges from a drastic re-hearing of the opening of Beethoven’s Ninth, as distant fanfares and tweeting birds usher us into Mahler’s world. A symphony, he would tell Jean Sibelius, must be a world, and this is his. The Wayfarer song is heralded by the unmistakable sound of the cuckoo. Unmistakable, but nonstandard: Austrian cuckoos, it seems, sing a fourth, rather than the traditional third.

One of Mahler’s early songs, Hans und Grete (another love song - inspiration, mercifully, unknown) is recycled in the second movement into a vision of precisely the pan-Germanic merriment that Mahler never felt at home in. Like the peasant dance in Bartók’s Concerto for Orchestra—once described as “a man trying to dance with a foot nailed to the floor”—this is music expressing almost exactly the opposite of what it seems to be. This is the music of the outsider, who always hears from afar, even when surrounded by the musicians.

Mahler knew Frère Jacques as Bruder Martin. Early audiences were violently offended by its transformation into a dirge in the third movement, as though it were an affront to the very thought of childish innocence. Which is exactly what it is. Mahler is at his grimmest precisely when he is joking. A lifelong admirer of Nietzsche, he was well acquainted with the philosopher’s motto—Ridendo dicere severum; saying stern things with a smile. Mahler claimed that the music was inspired by a woodcut called The Hunter’s Funeral Procession—which may even be true. But anyone who has been through the emotional mill of Stephen Sondheim’s Into The Woods knows what can happen to childish materials in the hands of a master. And so it is here.

Mahler’s own early program note calls the last movement of the symphony “The cry of a wounded heart”—his, of course. The movement acts as the apotheosis of the early movements—the goal they never reached. The Wayfarer of the first movement finally reaches his destination (it is almost a surprise that he had one); even poor Marion Weber makes an appearance as the Blumine music drifts achingly by—referring back, ironically, to music that Mahler had cut. The music, all too obviously, is conjuring up an ecstasy that he never knew in the “real” world (is there one?); the blaze of brass (seven horns!) that closes the work is an invitation into the Beyond. Jean-Paul once said, in a phrase that would echo eternally in Nietzsche, “Joy, unlike seriousness, is inexhaustible.” Mahler clearly knew what he meant; he had learned the hard way. Through his music, we can learn the same lesson.

fields.title: Tickets
fields.content:
Ticket Information

We have 2010-2011 season tickets waiting for you! We provide many methods for you to choose from: use a credit card to order online, send a check by mail, reserve tickets by phone/e-mail or purchase them in person at any of several different locations. Details for each method are given below. If you do not order in advance, the remaining available tickets can be purchased by cash or check at the performance.

Tickets purchased prior to September will be mailed in early September.

Subscription Ticket Prices: (Save 20% when you get 5 concerts for the price of 4!)

Adult $80
Seniors (60 and up) $64
Fulltime Students (To age 24) $40

Single Ticket Prices - Classical Concerts:

Adult $20
Seniors (60 and up) $16
Fulltime Students (To age 24) $10
Group Rates (10 or more) $16

Single Ticket Prices - Pops Concert:

Adult $22
Seniors (60 and up) $18
Fulltime Students (To age 24) $10
Group Rates (10 or more) $18

Single Ticket Prices - Young People's Concert:

Adults, children 12 and up $15
Children under 12 FREE

Subscriber Benefits Include:

Savings of 20%! Attend five concerts for the price of four.

Early access to seating! Subscribers may select the best seats in the house by entering the theatre ten minutes before single-ticket purchasers.

Free ticket exchange! When conflicts arise, exchange your ticket in advance for another program.

Special highlights on upcoming events! Receive early information about programs and guest artists.

E-mail reminders! Don't miss a single concert.


Tickets may be purchased in advance in any of the following four ways. All ticket orders placed within six days of a performance will be held at the concert's will-call window . They may be picked up any time after 6:15 p.m. on the evening of the performance.

1) Order online using a credit card. All transactions are handled on a secure server hosted by PayPal (the same PayPal that is the most trusted and popular method to make purchases on ebay). In the table below, simply click the "add to cart" button(s) for the ticket(s) you wish to purchase and follow the instructions. Your order will be confirmed by e-mail, and your tickets will be mailed to you (or held at will-call for orders placed within 6 days of the concert). Online orders will be accepted up until the morning of each concert. We would appreciate it, though, if you would order earlier as we are a bit busy concert day.

Please note: Online ordering is currently the only way to use a credit card to purchase tickets other than going in person to the Columbia Association office on Wincopin Circle. We are not equipped to handle credit card purchases at the door.

2) Order by mail. Tell us the concert date, type of tickets (senior, adult, student) and number of tickets for each type along with a check to The Columbia Orchestra. Send to the address at the bottom of the page.

3) Order by phone or e-mail. We strongly encourage online payment in order to minimize your delay in the lobby prior to being seated. If you do not wish to pay online and would like to reserve tickets to purchase at will-call, please contact our Executive Director at (410) 465-8777, extension 2, or E-mail ticketinfo@columbiaorchestra.org.

4) Purchase tickets in person. Tickets may be purchased in person at the Music & Arts Center at the Chatham Station Shopping Center, the Music & Arts Center in Laurel, or the Columbia Association office on Wincopin Circle. Music & Arts will accept payment by cash or check. Credit cards may be used at the Columbia Association office. Tickets are available at these locations shortly before each concert.

For those concerts which are not sold out in advance, tickets will be available for purchase (by cash or check only) at the door.




Concert Tickets 2010-2011

For each desired item, click once on its 'Add to Cart' button. The first click will cause a Paypal shopping cart window to appear. Quantities for each item can be changed or removed in this new window. To access the shopping cart window (without adding items), click the 'View Cart' button.

View current contents of shopping cart

fields.title: Volunteer
fields.content:
Volunteer Opportunities

The Columbia Orchestra is very grateful for all the volunteers who donate their time and talents at concerts and in our office.

If you would like to volunteer, please send an email to our Volunteer Director. We'd love to have you!

fields.title: Young Artist Competition 2010
fields.content:
Young Artist Competition 2009-2010

The 2009-2010 Young Artist competition took place on January 23 & 24, 2010. The players were outstanding, and we only wish that we could name more of them as winners. We are delighted to announce that the winners are:

Qian Mei, violin – Junior Division

Qian Mei is currently an 8th grader at Burleigh Manor Middle School. Qian has been studying violin for five years. For the past four years, she has been studying with Dr. Sheng-Tsung Wang. Qian has been a member of the Howard County GT and Enrichment Orchestras since 4th grade. She also participates in the Maryland All State Junior Orchestra.

Qian is also actively involved with the Burleigh Manor Mathalon team and the school newsletter committee, and she played volleyball in afterschool intramurals. Apart from school related activities, Qian loves play badminton. Qian also enjoys reading mystery novels, watching movies, making origami, and baking.

Alternate:

  • Samuel Choi, violin

Honorable Mentions:

  • Sarah Kim, violin
  • Nathan Ko, clarinet
  • Kenneth Ryu Naito, violin
  • Joseph Aaron Michael Smith, clarinet
  • Winnie Tsao, cello

Jenny Lehtonen, flute – First Place, Senior Division, Wind Category

Jenny Lehtonen is a 17-year-old junior at Oakland Mills High School in Columbia. She has played flute for seven years and currently studies with Marlee Lindon. She is a member of the Oakland Mills High School Wind Ensemble and Marching Band, and the Chapelgate Church Orchestra.

Jenny was the winner of the Junior Division of the 2006–2007 Flute Society of Washington Student Honors Competition and 2008 winner of the Greater Laurel and Columbia MTA Young Musician Competition. She has been a member of the Maryland All-State 2008 Junior Band, 2009 Senior Band, and 2010 Senior Orchestra.

Alternate:

  • Elizabeth Kim, flute

Honorable Mentions:

  • Kelley Klomparens, oboe
  • Felix Lee, clarinet
  • James Zhan, clarinet

Rena Shi, violin – First Place, Senior Division, String Category

Rena Shi, age 16, is a junior and an honor-roll student at River Hill High School. She began playing violin when she was three, and has been studying violin since with Ms. Ning Ma. She has been a member of the Maryland All State Orchestras every year since 2006, and is the principal second violin this year. Rena is the co-concertmaster and soloist of the River Hill High School Orchestra and the assistant concertmaster of the Howard County High School GT Orchestra. She recently won the River Hill/Marriotts Ridge High School Young Artist Competition and gave a solo performance with the River Hill/Marriotts Ridge High School Orchestra

A resident of Clarksville, Rena is also a competitive tennis player. She has won many USTA junior tournaments and in 2008 was among the top eight in her age group in Maryland. In the 2009 season, after winning all of her matches, she attained the title of Howard County Girl’s Single Champion and Tennis Player of the Year.

Alternate:

  • Alan Zhang, violin

Honorable Mentions:

  • Evangeline Chandran, violin
  • Samantha Cody, violin
  • Julie LeDuc, violin
  • Jonathan Terry, cello

The winners will perform with the orchestra at our concert on Saturday, March 27, 2010, at the Jim Rouse Theatre. All winners, alternates and honorable mentions receive two complementary tickets to the performance. Come hear the future of music in Howard County!

fields.title: Young Artist Competition
fields.content:
Young Artist Competition

The Columbia Orchestra is pleased to announce its Young Artist Competition for 2010–2011. This event is open to all students of string, wind, and percussion instruments through 12th grade who currently reside, attend school, or receive music instruction in Howard County. Previous first place winners are not eligible to reenter the same division. Please help us run the best possible event by reading and following all current policies.

CATEGORIES AND DIVISIONS

The 2010–2011 Columbia Orchestra Young Artist Competition will have two divisions:

  • JUNIOR—through 8th grade
  • SENIOR—9th through 12th grade

The Senior Division now has two separate categories: STRING (violin, viola, cello, and bass) and WINDS AND PERCUSSION (woodwind, brass, and percussion). The Junior Division will continue to have only one category: INSTRUMENTAL (to include all string, woodwind, brass, and percussion instruments). There is no piano category in either division. Only one application per individual is permitted; multiple applications on different instruments will not be accepted.

COMPETITION SCHEDULE

Monday, December 20, 2010: Postmark deadline for entry forms
Wednesday, January 12, 2011: Individual audition times will be posted on this web page
Saturday, January 29, 2011, 10:30 AM to 6:00 PM: Auditions
Sunday, January 30, 2011, 2:00 PM to 8:00 PM: Auditions
Saturday, February 5, 2011, 10:30 AM to 6:00 PM: Auditions Snow Date
Sunday, February 6, 2011, 2:00 PM to 8:00 PM: Auditions Snow Date
Saturday, March 26, 2011, 7:30 PM: Columbia Orchestra concert featuring winners

AUDITION PROCESS

All entrants will be scheduled to audition on Saturday, January 29, and/or Sunday, January 30, 2011, at Christ Episcopal Church, 6800 Oakland Mills Road, Columbia, MD 21045. Snow dates are Saturday, February 5, and Sunday, February 6, 2011. A tuned grand piano will be provided for accompanists. Large percussion equipment may be provided on request; please note requested instruments on your application form for a determination in advance.

Three professional judges from outside Howard County will select a Junior Division Instrumental winner, a Senior Division String winner, and a Senior Division Wind/Percussion winner. Judges may elect not to choose a winner in any or all categories.

Audition judges will write critiques, name Winners and Alternates, and award Honorable Mentions. Winners of the competition will be selected on January 29 and 30, 2011, and will perform with the Columbia Orchestra on Saturday, March 26, 2011, in the Jim Rouse Theatre. Winners will be announced at the completion of auditions, and certificates of participation will be mailed to each participant. The decision of the judges is final and not subject to protest. All participants will receive two complimentary tickets to the Columbia Orchestra concert featuring the winners. The winners will each receive a nominal cash prize from the Shirley Mullinix Scholarship Fund, a complimentary portrait package valued at $300 from James Ferry Photography, and a $100 gift certificate from Gailes Violin Shop.

COMMUNICATION

The teacher/parent assumes responsibility for communicating all information concerning the competition to his/her student/child, and will ensure that entry forms are accurately and completely filled out and mailed by the postmarked deadline. Entry forms must be postmarked by Monday, December 20, 2010. Late and/or incomplete entries will not be accepted. Please check this web page after January 12, 2011, for individual audition times. Teachers/parents must supply copies of all information received to their students/children and accompanists.

REPERTOIRE REQUIREMENTS

Entrant’s total performance may include one movement of any standard concerto, a single-movement work, or one, two, or three movements of not more than fifteen (15) minutes total performance from a suite, divertimento, or concertino. There is no required repertoire list; teachers should provide guidance in selecting level-appropriate literature for the student.

An original, published copy of the music must be presented to the judges at the competition. Memorization is optional. Any questions concerning repertoire should be directed to Jason Love, Music Director, at 410-465-8777.

A teacher may enter a maximum of three students playing the same movement of the same concerto. No changes in repertoire will be allowed after the application is submitted. Entry forms cannot be resubmitted with replacement repertoire.

All repertoire is accepted subject to the availability of orchestra accompaniment parts. Teachers/parents must check the availability of orchestra parts for all repertoire and indicate this on the entry form. (This information is available through most music stores.) Some accompaniments are only available through foreign publishers or on rental, and may cost $500 or more. The Columbia Orchestra shall not incur any cost above $200 to acquire the orchestral accompaniment. Should the applicant choose to perform repertoire that exceeds this limit, he/she shall be responsible for any additional expenses incurred. Parents and teachers must acknowledge their understanding and acceptance of this policy on the registration form.

Photocopied music will not be accepted and will result in automatic disqualification. The original, published music that students submit for the judges is in addition to the published music used by the student and/or accompanist.

ACCOMPANISTS

Each contestant will be responsible for providing his/her own accompanist for the auditions. Teachers and parents may accompany their own child/student.

When possible, accompanists with more than one contestant will be scheduled as close as possible within the same division. If an accompanist’s name is not on the entry form, adjacent performances cannot be scheduled.

Teachers/parents are responsible for notifying accompanists of the audition schedule posted on the Columbia Orchestra website at www.columbiaorchestra.org/youngartists.shtml. Accompanists’ requests to alter the published schedule will not be honored.

VIDEOTAPING

During the auditions, a parent/teacher may only videotape his/her child/student. Videotaping of other contestants is not permitted. Parents may videotape the Columbia Orchestra concert featuring the competition winners from a specified location in the performance venue. Anyone videotaping at the auditions or concert must abide by Columbia Orchestra policies and not interfere with the auditions or presentation of the concert. The concert will also be professionally recorded (audio only), with a compact disc copy provided to the winners.

APPLICATION PROCESS

A separate copy of the enclosed entry form must be completed for each applicant and must be signed by the student, parent/guardian, and teacher. Incomplete entry forms will not be accepted.

An entry fee of $45.00 must be included for each application. Checks or money orders must be made payable to The Columbia Orchestra, and may be submitted by either parents or teachers. (This fee does not include the services of an accompanist.)

The entry form and application fee must be postmarked by Monday, December 20, 2010. The Columbia Orchestra Young Artist Competition offers a unique opportunity for students. In order to produce this event, the cooperation and compliance with all stated policies is required by the students, parents, and teachers.

CONTACT INFORMATION
